GENERAL STATEMENT OF THE FILM;
This film makes the same statement in general as that made by
the film in Kit No* 5. To confront the student with television,
to see that he receives the television lesson and the message it
imparts, is simply to bring that message to the threshold of
learning. It remains for the student himself, with the skillful
guidance of his teachers, to move the message across the last three
difficult vital inches... from his eye and his ear to his brain_
where learning takes place.
This film concerns inself with exemplifying the ways in which
the high school teacher may integrate the television lesson into
the previous learnings and the ongoing experiences of students
in order to insure maximum learning, it points out that the
television segments of any unit of study must be...or be made to be...
an integral part of that unit...that the students must be aware
of the relationship of the television segment to the total learning
situation...that the classroom teacher must control the use of the
tllevision segment to create a wholesome, dynamic learning situation.
We see the teacher working with a specific group as introduction
to the large-group viewing of the television lesson to come. This
is a social studies lesson on WORLD CULTURES. We observe the
television teacher's presentation (where primary concern is with
the elements common to all learners)...see how this large-group
presentation enables other teachers to improve their approaches
to individual or special needs and problems for their particular
students...watch the varied approaches designed to follow-through
on the lesson concepts in the light of individual and group dif¬
ferences. ^

Teachers are reminded that however we may improve the instruments
of learning, learning still takes place...not in the television
studio...not on the television screen...but in the minds of the
